page.title: 06HAILES ABBEY (OR 050300)
page.content: Hailes Abbey was a Cistercian House. The Cistercian Order was founded in 1098. The Abbey itself was founded in 1246 by Richard, Earl of Cornwall who was one of the sons of King John. The Abbey was granted a yearly rent of 20 marks by Henry III in 1251. The Holy Blood was given to the Abbey in 1270 by Edmund, Earl of Cornwall. The Abbey became an important centre of pilgrimage. The Hailes Psalter and the Book of the Abbey were produced there. But in 1538 Thomas Cromwell, acting for Henry VIII removed the Holy Blood to London, calling it an "unctuous gum, coloured". On December 24 Abbot Sogar surrendered the Abbey. He and 21 monks were given pensions and wages were paid to 70 servants. The Abbey was pulled down and the stone used for local buildings.
